abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Third National Seeds Project (NSP III)
            in India. The objectives of NSP III were to: (a) reorient
            the operations of national and state level public sector
            seed corporations along commercial lines; (b) stimulate
            greater private sector investment (including in research and
            development); (c) improve the management of public sector
            variety development programs, and increase the quantity and
            improve the quality of breeder seeds produced; and (d) make
            seed industry regulation and control more effective. The
            main lessons learned during project implementation are as
            follows: The project has demonstrated that it is possible to
            commercialize the operations of public sector enterprises
            providing it is well planned and there is government
            commitment to change. However, the experiences of both State
            Seed Corporation (SSCs) and certification agencies clearly
            indicate that reform, leading to the commercialization of
            public sector organizations, is less effective when the
            chief executive of an organization is deputed from another
            government department or agency. The project has
            demonstrated the importance of the private sector. Subsidies
            could discourage private participation and could easily miss
            the target groups. Subsidies are currently paid only to SSCs
            or the supply of certified seed of new varieties (up to 10
            years) of Open Pollinated Varieties (OPV) such as rice and
            wheat. Public sector involvement in the supply of quality
            OPV Seed. The public sector will also remain the principal
            supplier of quality seed in remote areas where transport
            costs absorb any marginal profit from producing such seed.
